column2: statement
column4: article_summary

column2: A video shows the Russian warship Moskva exploding.
column4: The original source of the false video showing the sinking of the Moskva was a military exercise conducted by the Norwegian Navy in 2013. The navy blasted one of its own decommissioned ships with a missile to test out new weaponry.

column2: “Abigail Spanberger still votes with and shares Joe Biden’s positions 100% of the time.”
column4: Republican candidate Yesli Vega claims that incumbent Democrat Rep. Abigail Spanberger votes with and shares President Joe Biden's positions 100% of the time. To support this claim, Vega cites specific votes that Spanberger has made in alignment with Biden's agenda. Spanberger has voted to expand firearm regulations, cap out-of-pocket insulin costs, strengthen voting rights laws, expand debt limits, protect abortion rights, invest $1.2 trillion in infrastructure, and provide $1.9 trillion for COVID-19 relief. However, Spanberger has also shown some disagreement with certain aspects of Biden's policies, such as those related to the U.S.-Mexico border.

column2: “The Walker-Kleefisch administration slashed $800 million from public schools."
column4: The state Democratic Party of Wisconsin continues to claim that the Walker-Kleefisch administration slashed $800 million from public schools. However, similar claims have been debunked in the past. While the administration did cut close to that amount in a single two-year budget, it overlooks the money saved through Act 10 and subsequent funding increases that have restored a large portion of the reduction. Media reports provided by the Democratic Party of Wisconsin acknowledge both sides of the equation, but the claim remains largely unchanged.

column2: Esta grabación muestra una llamada al 911 de los migrantes atrapados en un camión en San Antonio, Texas.
column4: President Joe Biden states that the initial reports indicate human smuggling or trafficking as the cause of the incident in San Antonio. He expresses condolences and vows to prevent exploitation of migrants by criminal traffickers. Officials have arrested four men in connection with the incident, with one being accused of smuggling resulting in death, another charged with conspiracy, and the remaining two facing weapons offenses.

column2: “Gas prices have been going up since the president’s first day in office, starting with his move to shut down the Keystone XL pipeline.”
column4: Gas prices and crude oil prices have been on an upward trajectory throughout President Biden's tenure. There is no evidence that Biden's action on the Keystone XL pipeline caused an increase in gas prices. Gas prices were already rising due to increased demand following the easing of pandemic restrictions. The most recent spike in gas prices is largely due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Despite U.S. Senator Joni Ernst's claim, gas prices did not simply turn upward after Biden took office or canceled the Keystone XL pipeline.

column2: An image of a newspaper article says “True Bethel Baptist Church becomes the first church in NYS to receive a liquor license.”
column4: An image of a newspaper headline is being shared on social media, falsely claiming that True Bethel Baptist Church in upstate New York has obtained a liquor license, allegedly becoming the first church in the state to do so. However, there are no credible reports from the Buffalo News or any other news organization to support this. Furthermore, a search on the New York State Liquor Authority website showed no results regarding the church's liquor license. True Bethel Baptist Church has confirmed that they do not possess a liquor license and that the image is a fabrication.

column2: Says Joe Biden “shut down travel from 8 countries in response to the Omicron variant, but he refuses to require a #COVID19 test for illegal immigrants crossing our Southern border.”
column4: There is no widespread testing by federal agencies at the southern border. Local governments are relied upon for testing.

column2: “Soldiers destroyed Russian tank with NLAW in ambush.”
column4: Facebook post claims soldiers destroyed Russian tank with NLAW in ambush; video is an animation, not real footage of war in Ukraine. Soldiers on top of the tank and tank movements resemble simulation or video game. Animation merges with one soldier's arm. Previous claims of video game footage showing fighting in Ukraine have been debunked.

column2: Joe Biden's “$4 trillion” Build Back Better bill is "the largest expansion of welfare programs in 60 years."
column4: Carla Sands attacks Biden's Build Back Better bill, claiming it would be the largest expansion of welfare programs in 60 years. Build Back Better would spend $1.75 trillion over 10 years, with funding for social safety-net programs and climate change initiatives. Experts agree that the bill would be a significant expansion of social welfare programs. It's compared to the Great Society of the 1960s, which included various initiatives addressing poverty, environmental protection, education, and more.

column2: Images show how climate change destroyed the Greenland ice sheet and harmed a polar bear from 2009 to 2019.
column4: Jennifer Francis from the Woodell Climate Research Center points to studies indicating that polar bears' health is decreasing due to rapid sea ice loss. Polar bears require sea ice to capture sea lions. However, Mark Serreze, director of the National Snow and Ice Data Center, explains that there is no direct connection between the ice loss in Greenland and the condition of the distressed polar bear. The Greenland ice sheet's changes and polar bears' health are two separate issues caused by different factors.

column2: U.S. imports 1% of its oil from Russia while “Exxon, Chevron, BP and Shell profits are at their highest level in over 7 years.”
column4: Economic sanctions imposed by the U.S., European Union, and Japan have disrupted Russia's financial system, including its oil industry. President Joe Biden has announced a ban on Russian oil imports, which is expected to further increase gas prices in the U.S.

column2: “Inflation has gone up every month of the Biden presidency and just hit another 40-year high.”
column4: Data from the Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED) shows the inflation rate is at its highest point in 40 years, reaching 8.5% in March 2022. Inflation has been increasing every month since Biden took office, except for a slight plateau in mid-2021. Gallagher claims inflation has gone up every month of Biden's presidency, which is mostly true. Rising inflation is attributed to factors like increased consumer spending and supply chain issues.

column2: “Moderna has been pulled in Iceland and pulled for everyone under age 30 in Finland, Sweden, Norway, Denmark due to heart issues.”
column4: A viral Facebook post claiming that Moderna has been pulled in Iceland and for everyone under age 30 in Scandinavian countries due to heart issues is inaccurate. Iceland continues to administer Moderna for booster shots for those 60 and older. Among the listed countries, only Sweden temporarily suspended the use of Moderna for all people under 30. Finland limits Moderna to men and boys under 30. Norway recommends Pfizer over Moderna for certain individuals but does not prohibit anyone from taking Moderna. Denmark clarified that people under 18 can still request Moderna.

column2: Says CNN reported Queen Elizabeth II died.
column4: Hollywood Unlocked, an obscure U.S. blog, claimed that Queen Elizabeth II had passed away. The story went viral, with Variety reporting on the suspicious nature of the blog breaking the news before British outlets.

column2: “39 out of 42 (countries) in Europe have more restrictive abortion laws” than Mississippi.
column4: Governor Reeves relied on a study by the Charlotte Lozier Institute to support his claim about European abortion laws, but the study's definition of 'elective' abortions may not align with how the term is interpreted in different countries.

column2: "According to Republican Rep. Jeff Shipley, teachers should not receive a pay raise if they teach American history that Republicans don’t agree with."
column4: Rep. Jeff Shipley introduced and later withdrew an amendment to a school funding bill that would have tied teacher pay raises to compliance with a ban on divisive concepts in public school teaching. Shipley clarifies that teachers who teach ideas like inherent racism or tenets of Critical Race Theory should not receive pay raises. While lawmakers do not directly approve pay raises for teachers, they affect school boards' available money by approving state funding for school districts.

column2: “Jen Kiggans’ campaign confirmed today that she would support a national abortion ban.”
column4: U.S. Rep. Elaine Luria, R-Virginia, claims Rep. Jen Kiggans supports a national abortion ban, referring to a bill introduced by U.S. Sen. Lindsey Graham that would ban abortion after 15 weeks. However, Kiggans has not explicitly endorsed the bill and her stance on abortion is unclear. Luria's claim is based on a vague statement made by a spokesman for Kiggans' campaign. The bill is unlikely to pass and President Biden is likely to veto it if it does. Kiggans' position on the bill remains unclear.

column2: The Biden administration inherited gains of “50,000 jobs a month. We're now finally back to 500,000 jobs a month. We inherited a country where 4,000 people a day were dying from Covid. That's now down 75%.”
column4: Klain exaggerates decline in COVID-19 deaths under Biden compared to Trump; Daily average of deaths decreased by 61% under Biden; Jan. 20 had higher death total than seven-day rolling average.

column2: Every time a Republican has been elected president over the last few decades, House Democrats have objected to the result
column4: Derek T. Muller, a professor at the University of Iowa College of Law, documented the history of Democrats objecting to Republican presidential winners. House Democrats made objections in 2001, 2005, and 2017, but the objections were considered symbolic as the losing candidates had already conceded. In 2001, black voters in Florida being disenfranchised was a concern, but the objections were ultimately gaveled down by Vice President Al Gore. The objections made in prior years were regarded as disconcerting, even if they lacked the same intent to overturn the election results as the 2021 objections.

column2: “Fully vaccinated Australians in hospital for COVID-19 surpass unvaccinated”
column4: Headline misrepresents data; experts confirm vaccines' effectiveness

column2: About a federal hospital price transparency requirement, “Nobody’s enforcing that law.”
column4: Although hospitals have been slow to post the required price information, enforcement efforts are gradually ramping up. The transparency directive is a first-of-its-kind rule, leading to a learning curve for hospitals and regulators. However, experts point out that the availability of price data alone may not lead to a consumer revolution in healthcare, as patients often rely on recommendations from their doctors and may find it challenging to navigate the complex data. The ad by Power to the Patients continues to run despite improvements in enforcement.

column2: In 1975, then-U.S. Sen. Joe Biden opposed efforts by President Gerald Ford to aid South Vietnam and evacuate refugees.
column4: After Saigon fell to the North Vietnamese military, Biden supported a resolution welcoming the first 130,000 refugees from Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos to the U.S. Congress approved and Ford signed a separate measure authorizing funds to assist refugees from Vietnam and Cambodia, which Biden gave a favorable recommendation to. Despite the claim that Biden opposed efforts to aid South Vietnam and evacuate refugees, his statements and actions showed his priority was evacuating U.S. citizens and Vietnamese refugees while expressing concerns about military aid.

column2: Says Chuck Norris recorded a video in response to the Biden administration saying, “Our great country and freedom are under attack.”
column4: Chuck Norris expresses concern about the future of our country, warning against its potential shift towards socialism.

column2: “Zach Nunn took money from Adventureland’s CEO, then sponsored legislation to loosen amusement park safety rules. A child died. Zach Nunn put his big donor first, ahead of the safety of Iowa families.”
column4: An attack ad in Iowa's 3rd Congressional District campaign criticizes Zach Nunn, the Republican nominee, accusing him of prioritizing a big donor over the safety of Iowa families. The ad claims that Nunn sponsored legislation, House File 558, which loosened amusement park safety rules. However, Nunn's campaign disputes this, stating that the legislation aimed to improve workforce opportunities and minimize unemployment in Iowa. Additionally, the ad suggests that Gov. Kim Reynolds signed the bill into law, and Nunn's response refutes the ad's claims. Paige Godden, a representative from Cindy Axne's campaign, defends the ad's messaging.

column2: Falleció el papa emérito Benedicto XVI.
column4: A false claim about the death of Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI circulated on Instagram. The rumor originated from a Twitter account impersonating Georg Bätzing, the President of the German Episcopal Conference. The Vatican and legitimate news sources have not confirmed the alleged death. The Council of Latin American Bishops labeled it as false. Tommasso Debenedetti, known for spreading fake news, and the @BischofBatzing Twitter account were involved in the false claim.

column2: The Biden administration "published a study concluding 4 (of) 5 new cars on the road by 2050 will still require liquid fuels."
column4: Iowa, the leading state in biofuel production from farm crops, has a capacity to produce 4.6 billion gallons of biofuels, double that of the second-ranking state, Nebraska. The biofuels industry in Iowa, supported by congressional members from both parties, urges President Joe Biden to fulfill his promise of expanding support for biofuels. This call for support stems from the fact that 79% of vehicles on the road in the United States are projected to require liquid fuels, and biofuels are an essential component of that category.

column2: “Florida Highway Patrol has a semi-truck … The FHP uses a fleet of three such ‘hidden in plain sight’ trucks to snitch on bad drivers.”
column4: Facebook post reveals that Florida Highway Patrol (FHP) uses semitrucks as patrol vehicles to snitch on bad drivers and occasionally make traffic stops.

column2: “Mike Lee advised Trump's legal challenges to overturn our election” and “was one of only two senators who was in on the scheme.”
column4: Kael Weston is campaigning as a Democrat; Pressure on the Utah Democratic Party to not field a candidate in hopes of boosting McMullin's chances; The Utah race could impact which party controls the Senate.

column2: Scam artists are using Amazon to send people face masks laced with “something toxic.”
column4: Local police have not heard of any reports of toxic masks in unsolicited packages. The U.S. Postal Inspection Service advises calling the police or following their suspicious-mail page if there are safety concerns about the package.

column2: “In Texas, because of the laws they passed, a 95-year-old World War II veteran is being denied the right to vote by mail because he can't produce a registration number he got back in the 1950s.”
column4: The Texas Secretary of State's office advises county officials and voters who lack ID information on their voter registration record to update their records. The state's new elections law, requiring ID information on mail ballot applications, has caused confusion and rejections. The office reports that as of December 20, around 100,000 registered Texas voters do not have identification numbers on their voter registration records. While Kenneth Thompson, a World War II veteran, is able to update his registration and apply for a mail ballot, concerns remain about other senior citizens who may struggle to navigate the process.

column2: “Finland joins NATO.”
column4: Finland plans to join NATO in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, pending parliamentary approval. Turkey has expressed concerns about Finland's NATO membership, but it doesn't intend to block it. Once Finland formally applies, there may be a quick ratification process by member countries of around six months.

column2: “Zack Nunn saved over 2,000 Americans abandoned in Afghanistan by leading private rescue missions.”
column4: Jesse Jensen, co-founder of Task Force Argo along with Zach Nunn, has been helpful in supporting a bill called the Afghan Adjustment Act, which aims to give Afghan immigrants permanent legal residency and a pathway to U.S. citizenship. Task Force Argo has collaborated with other groups like #AfghanEvac and has been commended for their efforts in assisting Afghans and providing much-needed support. While the ad for Zach Nunn's congressional campaign exaggerated the number of Americans saved, Nunn and Task Force Argo have been actively involved in the evacuation of Americans and at-risk Afghan nationals.

column2: “As the world rallies around Ukraine, Mike Lee was one of only two senators to oppose sanctions on Putin. Then he flew to the Kremlin and discussed dropping sanctions. Lee even opposed arming Ukrainians fighting for their lives.”
column4: Leading Democrats are urging support for independent candidate Evan McMullin in an effort to defeat two-term Republican Sen. Mike Lee in Utah's U.S. Senate race. The race in heavily Republican Utah could play a role in determining Senate control, which is currently split 50-50. McMullin's campaign has raised more money than Lee's in the final quarter of 2021. Although the race is considered safe Republican, some Democrats believe a Democrat cannot win statewide in Utah. Lee is also facing primary challenges from Becky Edwards and Ally Isom.

column2: In his election as governor, “We won cities that no Republican had ever won.”
column4: In the 2021 Virginia gubernatorial election, Glenn Youngkin and his running mates became the first Republicans to win a statewide election in Virginia since 2009. Youngkin won with 50.6% of the vote, defeating Democrat Terry McAuliffe. Youngkin's claim that he won cities that no Republican had ever won before is fact-checked and proven false. He won 14 cities, all of which had been previously won by another Republican candidate in past elections.

column2: “Only 16% Of Canadians Would SUPPORT Trudeau After Trucker Protest!”
column4: CNN refuted claims made by a Fox contributor and the right-wing Washington Examiner that only 16% of Canadians want Trudeau back as prime minister or would vote for him again based on the poll about his handling of the trucker protest. The poll did not ask participants if they would support or vote for Trudeau, so it is not accurate to make those claims. The Facebook post distorts the meaning of the poll results.

column2: Abortion is available at any point of pregnancy and for any reason in Alaska, Colorado, New Jersey, New Mexico, Oregon and Vermont.
column4: Focus on the Family celebrated the Supreme Court's decision on Roe v. Wade, and later ran ads against late-term abortions in certain states. These ads made exaggerated claims about the availability of abortions throughout the entire nine months of pregnancy in certain states. While the laws in Alaska, Colorado, New Jersey, New Mexico, Oregon, and Vermont do not explicitly prohibit abortions at any stage of pregnancy, abortions later in pregnancy are rare and usually only performed for urgent medical reasons. The CDC reports that less than 1% of abortions are performed at or after 21 weeks of pregnancy.

column2: "Ron Johnson has voted against funding for law enforcement and recently opposed a plan to recruit and train new officers "
column4: Barnes accuses Johnson of voting against funding for law enforcement and opposing a plan to recruit and train new officers. However, the evidence for both claims is weak. Johnson's vote against the American Rescue Plan Act does not equate to voting against law enforcement funding. The relief package provided flexibility for state and local governments to use funds for essential workers, including law enforcement, but it did not guarantee direct support. It is crucial to distinguish between one-time cash injections and existing funding. Additionally, Johnson has backed measures and received endorsements from police groups, indicating Democratic support for law enforcement.

column2: "Over time there have been 160-some carve-outs to the filibuster."
column4: Past carve-outs have mostly been enacted through statutes, unlike the voting rights carve-out being proposed. However, if a voting rights carve-out is enacted, the line between carve-outs and filibuster reform may blur.

column2: Gov. Tony Evers has “only gotten one-third of the money meant for COVID relief out the door. He is sitting on $930 million in ARPA funds left unspent. In fact, he still has CARES Act money from two years ago.”
column4: As of Dec. 31, 2021, Wisconsin had expended or obligated nearly $750 million of the funding received through the American Rescue Plan Act, which is required to be allocated by the end of 2024 and spent by the end of 2026. This does not include programs announced in this year. Democratic Gov. Tony Evers' team argues that having nearly $750 million of funds expended or obligated within a year's time, with five years available to spend the funds, meets the definition of 'acting quickly.' Additionally, all $2 billion in CARES Act funding has been allocated, with only about 1% remaining to be spent.

column2: “Iowans are paying $5,000 extra for everyday goods under Biden and Axne’s inflation.”
column4: According to a report from the Republican side of Congress Joint Economic Committee, Iowans were projected to pay $7,997 more for goods in 2022 compared to January 2021, resulting in a 13.7% inflation rate since the start of 2021. However, the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reported an 8.1% inflation rate in the Midwest region over the past year. Republican Rep. Zach Nunn blames Democrats, including Cindy Axne and President Biden, for inflation, but experts argue that supply shortages and strong demand are also contributing factors.

column2: “When I became mayor of the City of Richmond in 2004, the crime rate was at its highest. When I left in 2008, it was at its lowest.”
column4: Addressing crime prevention requires a holistic approach that considers factors such as education, employment, poverty, housing, and health services. The increase in homicides in the US in 2020, and potentially 2021, is attributed to isolation, economic distress caused by COVID-19, and conflicts arising from social media use. Wilder's emphasis on public safety is aligned with the need for comprehensive strategies to address crime levels.

column2: "Deidre DeJear refused to stand for police."
column4: Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds released a campaign ad criticizing opponent Deidre DeJear for not standing for police during a state address. The ad shows a photo of DeJear sitting during a standing ovation for law enforcement. DeJear's campaign said she sat to protest Reynolds' lack of support for law enforcement. DeJear has consistently stated her support for programs that can help police, such as reducing recidivism and improving mental health care access. The 'Defund the Police' movement gained traction after the killing of George Floyd by Derek Chauvin.

column2: “Elon Musk just fired the entire Twitter board of directors.”
column4: Elon Musk's bid to buy Twitter has not been finalized yet.

column2: Binding masks to your face with gauze and wrapping pantyhose around your face and mask are now “suggestions to make your mask more ‘effective.’”
column4: In the study on improving mask fit, researchers tested the performance of KN95 and surgical masks with various 'fit hacks'. The researchers found that nearly all of the 'fit hacks' improved mask fit and effectiveness. The most effective hack was using a layer of pantyhose to hold the mask tightly to the face. However, the researchers mentioned that many of the 'fit hacks' were uncomfortable and may not be practical for everyday use.

column2: “Marco Rubio le ha votado en contra a los Dreamers”.
column4: A campaign ad on Facebook in Spanish criticizes Senator Marco Rubio for his votes on the DACA program, accusing him of voting against Dreamers and their dreams for a better future. The ad fails to mention that Rubio supported a proposal that included a pathway to citizenship for DACA recipients. While Rubio argues that the program was created illegally and should be replaced with a permanent legislative solution, he has expressed different views on when to end the program. Rubio believes Congress should address the issue instead of relying on the President's executive authority.

column2: “Overdoses in Virginia (are) up 35%.”
column4: Del. John McGuire, R-Goochland, blames President Biden for the surge in overdose deaths in Virginia. CDC estimates show a 35.5% increase in overdoses from April 2020 to April 2021. The Virginia Department of Health reported a 51% rise in drug fatalities from April 2020 to March 2021. Experts attribute the increase to the spread of fentanyl and the impact of the pandemic, including factors like the lockdown affecting access to treatment programs.

column2: Mo Brooks "voted to cut off funding to destroy ISIS terrorists in the middle of the fight."
column4: Alabama's Future, a super PAC, attacks U.S. Rep. Mo Brooks in ads for his bid for a Senate seat. The ads claim that Brooks voted to cut off funding for the fight against ISIS, but experts say the amendments he voted for were more about congressional war powers. The amendments, which took place in 2015 and 2016, were not direct votes on funding but required congressional authorization for military action against ISIS. Brooks is facing two other major GOP contenders, Katie Britt and Mike Durant, in the primary.

column2: Sen. Marco Rubio "helped write the law to raise prescription prices."
column4: Rubio's campaign argued that the Inflation Reduction Act provisions would harm drug innovation. Experts agree that higher drug prices could incentivize manufacturers to develop new drugs, but there is disagreement on the extent of the effects.

column2: A chart shows China and India are leading in per capita carbon dioxide emissions.
column4: Hannah Ritchie, a senior researcher for Our World in Data, explained that the significant increase in CO2 emissions in China and India compared to declines in the U.S. and other developed countries is due to the fact that China and India had low emissions in 1990 while the other countries already had high emissions. Ritchie also provided a different chart that shows the actual change in per capita emissions over time, with the U.S. and Japan leading in per capita CO2 emissions.

column2: In 2020, when Raphael Warnock ran a campaign ad featuring himself with a beagle, “that wasn’t his dog.”
column4: Warnock has owned dogs before, including Comet, Cupid, and Brenal, but didn't currently have a dog when the ad was filmed.

column2: Texas' public high school graduation rate is at 90% overall.
column4: Governor Greg Abbott's campaign praised the education system in Texas, highlighting wins in K-12 and higher education. Texas has a 90% overall high school graduation rate, with efforts to improve rates ongoing under Abbott's leadership. Texas has consistently ranked among the top states for high school graduation rates and surpasses the national average. The state is not afraid to make changes and try new strategies to improve education. Texas is making improvements in all metrics related to graduation rates and attrition rates.

column2: Says he led the fight to add 200 new police officers to make the City of Milwaukee safer.
column4: The 2020 COPS Hiring Program Grant provided federal funding to bring on new police officers in order to address violent crime. Acting Mayor Cavalier Johnson consistently voted in favor of this grant while it was being considered by the Common Council. The grant was approved and signed by then-Mayor Tom Barrett on January 19, 2021. This federal funding, combined with the funding for 195 new recruits, helped maintain the size of the Milwaukee Police Department's force.

column2: "U.S. households are on track to spend $19 billion more on energy by 2030."
column4: Williams' statistic of U.S. households spending $19 billion more on energy by 2030 is specific to a proposed ban on new leasing and development for oil and gas operations. Household energy prices are challenging to forecast due to various factors, including Biden's energy policies. According to the Energy Information Administration, under current laws and regulations, residential non-renewable energy expenditures are projected to increase by $18 billion.

column2: Image shows a Rebekah Jones campaign event.
column4: U.S. Rep. Matt Gaetz misleadingly compared support at his campaign event to that of his Democratic opponent. Gaetz's photo showed a crowded room of supporters, while the opponent's photo depicted a booth at a holistic wellness expo. However, the expo's owner confirmed it was not a political campaign event. The opponent, Rebekah Jones, explained that her son, who has autism, needed a quiet moment. Gaetz's claim neglects these critical facts and provides a false impression.

column2: Jim Jordan said, “It’s finally happening! Adam Schiff will be impeached.”
column4: ‘It's finally happening! Adam Schiff will be IMPEACHED’ - Brave Jim Jordan SHUTS DOWN Schiff,

column2: The World Economic Forum has called for the end of “wasteful private car ownership.”
column4: The World Economic Forum highlights the problem of unused cars and suggests car-sharing as a solution to free up resources for other uses. The forum's article emphasizes the need for a transition from ownership to usership to reduce the number of undriven cars and conserve precious metals used in clean energy technologies. It calls for a broader mindset that redesigns cities to reduce private vehicles and promotes the repurposing of car technologies, such as electric car batteries with remaining capacity.

column2: Video shows a “Russian pilot” escaping from jets and a Russian aircraft getting hit by a missile.
column4: Facebook flags video game footage amid Ukraine's war. The clip titled 'Russian pilot escapes from jets - Russian SU-25 hit by Missile' depicts firefights in the sky as helicopters and jets dodge enemy weapons. It is a clip from the video game Arma 3, causing confusion on Facebook.

column2: There are now zero students, staff or anyone “related to the school system” in Union County” hospitalized with COVID-19, despite harsh criticism of school COVID policy.
column4: Sandeep Patel, a physician and member of the SOS Union County group, has criticized the lack of temporary measures implemented by the Union County school board to reduce COVID-19 transmission. Patel argues that the response should be evaluated based on the board's actions during the worst surge in cases. While the Union County school system stated that no employees were hospitalized with COVID-19 on the day in question, it does not track the health status of individuals who work with the schools but are not school system employees.

column2: Virginia’s “education standards for math and reading are now the lowest in the nation.”
column4: Virginia's standards for reading and math in fourth and eighth grades were the lowest among measured states.

column2: Image claims to show a list of "Republican members of Congress whose PPP loans were forgiven."
column4: The Center for American Progress Action responds to Republican critics of student debt cancellation, such as the House Judiciary GOP, by sharing screenshots of Paycheck Protection Program loan forgiveness benefiting these same members.

column2: Kari Lake and Mark Finchem “have said that they will only honor the results of an election if they agree with it."
column4: Liz Cheney's ad criticizes Kari Lake and Mark Finchem for being election deniers. Lake, running for governor, has said she will accept the results of a fair, honest, and transparent election. Finchem, running for secretary of state, has not committed to certifying Arizona's vote in the 2024 presidential election. Cheney launched her political action committee after being defeated by Harriet Hageman, who was endorsed by Donald Trump. The PAC aims to educate the public about the threats to the republic and mobilize against any Trump campaign for president.

column2: Lee Zeldin “voted for abortion bans even when the mother’s health is at risk.”
column4: Doctors and experts argue that without a health exception, healthcare providers can be fearful about providing the necessary treatment. Dr. Jen Villavicencio said that the progression of pregnancy and associated complications vary, making a health exception necessary. Dr. Anthony Levatino argued that abortion isn't necessarily required later in pregnancy and that delivering the baby can save the mother's life.

column2: Video shows Donald Trump at an Alabama rally on July 13, 2022.
column4: A video falsely timestamped as live on Facebook shows former President Donald Trump at a rally in Cullman, Alabama on Aug. 21, 2021. The footage is authentic, but the timestamp is inaccurate. During the rally, Trump discussed President Joe Biden, the situation in Afghanistan, and recommended his supporters get a COVID-19 vaccine, which was met with boos.

column2: “Mandela Barnes…wants to release 50% of the prison population when 68% is classified as ‘violent offenders.’”
column4: Republicans criticize U.S. Senate candidate Mandela Barnes for his stance on crime and punishment, asserting that he wants to release 50% of Wisconsin's prison population, including violent offenders. However, Barnes advocates reducing the prison population gradually. The National Republican Senatorial Committee accuses Barnes based on his involvement with the 11x15 campaign. Data reveals that violent offenders make up 66% of the prison population, while property-related offenses account for 13%, drug-related offenses for 12%, and public order offenses for 9%.

column2: “An extra 2 whole months and 15 days. That’s how long it takes for white women to make the same amount men made in the same job last year. And it's even worse for women of color.”
column4: U.S. Sen. Tammy Duckworth claims the gender pay gap is bad for white women doing the same job as men and it's even worse for \

column2: “The Loudoun County School Board spent about $300,000 (last year) … to bring CRT in some form or fashion to the school system.”
column4: Lt. Gov. Winsome Earle-Sears claimed that Loudoun County School Board spent about $300,000 last year to bring critical race theory to the school system. However, records show that the money was spent between September 2018 and June 2020, primarily on equity efforts. While the school system did pay $34,167 for seminars on critical race theory, critics argue that the majority of the spending was focused on improving racial equity and fairness in schools, not on teaching CRT to students.

column2: "With three months remaining in the Fiscal Year, (the border patrol) has already encountered more illegal immigrants along the Southwest border" than in any previous fiscal year.
column4: Jessica Botler from the Migration Policy Institute noted that 2 million apprehensions at the southwest border does not mean 2 million migrants. It can be the same person attempting to cross multiple times. U.S. Customs and Border Protection explained that total encounters somewhat overstate the number of unique individuals arriving at the border due to the large number of expulsions during the pandemic. Representative Glenn Grothman accurately claims that the border patrol has already encountered more illegal immigrants along the Southwest border than in any previous fiscal year.

column2: Video shows a Ukrainian fighter pilot shooting down a Russian plane.
column4: A simulation video on Facebook claims to show the 'Ghost of Kyiv' (a Ukrainian MiG-29 fighter pilot) shooting down a Russian plane. However, the video is from a video game called Digital Combat Simulator. It is unclear whether the pilot actually exists. Reports suggest that the Ghost of Kyiv downed six Russian planes on the first day of the invasion, although experts doubt this. The Ukrainian Armed Forces reported shooting down five Russian aircraft and a helicopter, but the Russian military denied these reports. Former Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko referenced the Ghost of Kyiv in social media posts.

column2: “Wages have gone up higher, faster than inflation.”
column4: Biden said that 'wages have gone up higher, faster than inflation.' That was the case in August and September. But the gains from those two months are only starting to dig inflation-adjusted wages out of the hole they fell into during the first seven months of Biden’s tenure.

column2: “Most Americans on minimum wage earn less than a Dickensian allegory for destitution.”
column4: James Kincaid, an expert on Charles Dickens, disagrees with the claim made in a social media post regarding Bob Cratchit's wages in 'A Christmas Carol.' Kincaid argues that the post falsely suggests that organized labor efforts have made no progress, ignoring the gains made by workers. He explains that the average worker during the Victorian era worked long hours and that there is no straightforward way to convert Cratchit's wages to today's U.S. wages. Kincaid emphasizes that Dickens and his readers had a clear understanding of what constituted a barely-above-starvation wage for a worker like Cratchit and his family.

column2: An image shows “a medical oddity that is characterized by having two pupils in each eyeball.”
column4: Medical oddity Pupula duplex, featuring two pupils in an eye, goes viral on social media, astonishing ophthalmologists.

column2: Omicron is “the fastest-spreading virus known to humankind."
column4: The basic reproduction number (R0) indicates the average number of times a person transmits the virus. Measles has the highest R0 of 12 to 18, followed closely by the omicron variant of COVID-19, which has an R0 higher than the delta variant. The omicron variant is estimated to be 1.5 to 2 times more transmissible than delta, with each case infecting 7 to 14 people. Measles, however, continues to be the most contagious virus.

column2: Over a million people apprehended at the border this year, "meaning probably another 2 or 3 million have come in illegally."
column4: The potential reinstatement of Trump-era Migrant Protection Protocols, also called the Remain in Mexico policy, has been in flux since President Joe Biden took office. Biden ended the policy soon after taking office. The administration was ordered to reinstate these protocols by a federal court in Texas in August, and the Supreme Court upheld that decision. Customs and Border Protection reported a total of 1.7 million encounters with migrants at the southwestern border in the last fiscal year, with over 1 million individuals encountered year-to-date in fiscal 2021. Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick claimed that over a million people were apprehended this year, and estimated that another 2 or 3 million entered illegally based on law enforcement estimates.

column2: “Iowa ranks 45th in the U.S. for internet connectivity."
column4: BroadbandNow.com, which obtains its data from the Federal Communications Commission and the U.S. Census Bureau, ranks Iowa as the 45th state in the U.S. for broadband access. The FCC reported that nearly one-fourth of the population in rural America lacks access to broadband service, impacting 14.5 million people across the country. The U.S. Census Bureau reported that between 2015 and 2019, 80.8% of Iowa households had broadband internet subscriptions. Out of all the states, Iowa had a smaller percentage of households with subscriptions compared to 16 other states.

column2: Cheri Beasley voted to reverse the conviction of an armed kidnapper, release a double murderer early.
column4: The NRSC ad claims that Cheri Beasley reversed the conviction of an armed kidnapper in State of North Carolina v. Ramar Dion Benjamin Crump and voted to grant early release to an armed double-murderer in State of North Carolina v. Bobby E. Bowden. In the Crump case, Beasley's vote was based on a fair trial violation relating to racial bias in jury selection. In the Bowden case, Beasley disagreed with the majority's decision that he was not eligible for sentence reduction despite accumulating credits for good behavior. Crump was released from prison last August, while Bowden died in 2019.

column2: A video shows people in Romania protesting COVID-19 vaccines.
column4: Misleading video being shared online does not show the protest against COVID-19 restrictions in Bucharest, Romania. The exact number of protesters is unknown, but estimates range from

column2: “You go to a store, they don’t have bread.”
column4: While a specific baked good might be briefly missing from grocery store shelves, customers generally have many other options as stores carry various varieties of bread.

column2: “It costs more to live in many Florida cities than New York City.”
column4: Florida residents are facing an affordable housing crisis due to rising rental prices and limited supply. The median rent in the Miami-Fort Lauderdale-West Palm Beach area has increased about 57% in the past year, surpassing that of New York City. However, other major metro areas in Florida, such as Tampa-St. Petersburg-Clearwater and Jacksonville, have lower median rents compared to New York City. Despite the rising rent prices in Florida, New York City remains one of the most expensive metros in the country in terms of actual rents and property prices.

column2: Republican state Sens. Paul Newton and Warren Daniel “refused to even give testimony” in North Carolina’s latest redistricting case.
column4: Sens. Paul Newton and Warren Daniel invoked legislative privilege under state laws and were exempted from depositions and testifying during the redistricting trial. While legislative privilege's scope is not well defined in the state law, legislators could still be compelled to answer certain questions. Sen. Ralph Hise, who testified, noted that the Senate redistricting process required maps to be drawn in public view, but no specific directive was issued banning staff from looking at concept maps outside of public view.

column2: "Iowa Republicans have introduced a bill that would put government-installed cameras in every single classroom to livestream school activities for parents to spy on teachers and children."
column4: The bill introduced in Iowa aims to install cameras in public school classrooms, allowing parents to watch a livestream of their child's class. The bill provides narrow exceptions for gym class and special education classrooms, and it envisions the livestream taking place over a secure platform like Zoom. The bill proposes using state funding to pay for the cameras, and it also aims to provide a record of classroom activities for teachers facing harassment. Similar bills have been proposed in Maryland, Texas, West Virginia, and Louisiana for special education classrooms.

column2: The percentage of vaccinated employees at United Airlines increased after the mandate because unvaccinated employees left the company.
column4: As of Oct. 13, United Airlines spokesperson Charles Hobart said that 232 employees were facing termination for failing to comply with the COVID-19 vaccine mandate.

column2: “Joe Biden holds the all-time record for the most money received from Pharma while in Congress! $8,550,422.”
column4: Among past and current members of Congress, Biden holds the record for drug industry contributions, at nearly $8.9 million. More than 99% of the drug industry money Biden collected came during his 2020 presidential campaign. The pharmaceutical industry contributed less than $70,000 to Biden’s Senate campaign committees from 1989 to 2008. He ranks 708th for contributions received while Congress.

column2: This image shows the victims of the school shooting in Uvalde, Texas.
column4: The Facebook post incorrectly claims to show the victims of the Uvalde school shooting. However, the photo collage actually shows the victims of the 2012 shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

column2: Adam Laxalt "supports eliminating Nevada's protections for legal abortions."
column4: Democratic Nevada Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto is drawing on fears about abortion restrictions to repel a challenge from Republican Adam Laxalt. A leaked draft Supreme Court opinion could overturn Roe v. Wade, potentially impacting abortion access in Nevada. Nevada law allows abortion through 24 weeks of pregnancy with exceptions for the woman's life or health. Even if Roe were overturned, Nevada's law would still protect abortion rights, but a national ban on abortion would supersede the state law.

column2: "Bill Gates and AOC say that a cow emits more pollution than a car."
column4: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez co-sponsored the Green New Deal, a proposed resolution to address climate change, which emphasizes the need to transition from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources. The resolution does not compare car emissions to those of cows. Ocasio-Cortez has advocated for addressing factory farming as a way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Although she has never specifically mentioned cows emitting more pollution than cars, she has talked about the need to eat less meat and reduce consumption of animal products to address climate change.

column2: “Since 2019, I've successfully lobbied for the funds to add hundreds of school counselors, lowering our student to school counselor ratio by 20%.”
column4: Kathy Hoffman began lobbying for additional funds to add more counselors before the COVID-19 pandemic. By 2021, Arizona had 1,552 counselors, an increase of 290 counselors in three years. The student to counselor ratio improved by about 20%. Federal COVID relief dollars facilitated staff increases and Hoffman allocated $21.3 million for schools to hire counselors and social workers in 2021.

column2: Says U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson, his prospective opponent, has received $1.2 million from the gun lobby.
column4: A Johnson campaign spokesperson, Alexa Henning, disputes the claim made by Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes and states that Johnson had minimal control or personal knowledge of the $1.2 million in support he received from pro-gun groups.

column2: "Karrin Taylor Robson gave illegals tuition discounts and made us pay for it."
column4: The Maricopa County Community College District began offering eligible DACA students in-state tuition by accepting their employment authorization as evidence of residency.

column2: Says Gov. Tony Evers gave $2.4 million in COVID relief money to Planned Parenthood affiliates throughout Wisconsin “to bail them out and fund abortions."
column4: Tony Evers allocated federal COVID relief funds to Planned Parenthood clinics in 21 locations throughout Wisconsin. The funds were not used for abortions. The Madison East location, Milwaukee's Water Street Health Center, and the Sheboygan clinic are the only clinics that provide abortion services, but they did not receive funds from the grant program.

column2: U.S. Rep. Mayra Flores is “the first Mexican-born member of Congress.”
column4: Rep. Mayra Flores, R-Texas, is not the first Mexican-born member of Congress. Rep. Lauren Boebert, R-Colo., mistakenly claimed that Flores is 'the first Mexican-born member of Congress' on a July 11 podcast. However, three current members of Congress were born in Mexico, including Rep. Raul Ruiz, D-Calif., Rep. Salud Carbajal, D-Calif., and Rep. Jesus 'Chuy' García, D-Ill. Additionally, former Rep. Carlos Bee, D-Texas, was born in Saltillo, Mexico.

column2: "Don Bolduc wants to cut trillions from Medicare and end Social Security."
column4: Bolduc continued to call for big Medicare changes during his 2022 campaign, including privatizing it. Bolduc addressed his August comments in two subsequent interviews. According to audio and video clips cited by Hassan’s campaign, a man at one event asked how Bolduc would ensure that the man would receive his full Social Security benefits. Bolduc said 'we need to invest in Social Security' for current recipients and those soon to be receiving Social Security, but for people who are now roughly 45 or 50 years or old or younger, 'we’re going to develop a new program for you.

column2: "Joe Biden is giving smartphones away to illegal border crossers.”
column4: The SmartLINK monitoring program, which utilizes smartphones to track immigrants released from custody, has been used by past administrations, including the Trump administration. The claim made by conservative pundit Nick Adams that the issuance of smartphones to illegal border crossers is an impeachable offense for Biden does not hold up. The Constitution states that a sitting president can be removed from office for 'treason, bribery or other high crimes and misdemeanors', but Adams fails to provide any evidence that the provision of smartphones meets these criteria. The claim is without merit.

column2: “Ninety-two percent of abortions in Virginia take place before 15 weeks.”
column4: U.S. Rep. Bob Good urges Republicans to reject Virginia Gov. Glenn Youngkin's proposed abortion compromise and protect life from conception. Good argues that the compromise, banning most abortions at 15 weeks and potentially extending to 20 weeks, would only ban a small percentage of abortions (1%). Good supports 'The Life at Conception Act' and criticizes Youngkin and a panel of Republican negotiators for being open to a deal that targets just 1% of abortions in Virginia. Democrats in the General Assembly are divided on the issue.

column2: Says J.D. Vance said, “People who voted for Trump voted for him for racist reasons.”
column4: Club for Growth Action, a super PAC backing Josh Mandel, ran a deceptive ad claiming J.D. Vance said 'people who voted for Trump voted for him for racist reasons'. The ad selectively edited Vance's words, omitting crucial context where Vance emphasized that most Trump voters were motivated by jobs, not racial animus. The interviewer had asked Vance about the role of race in Trump's win.

column2: "We've had two members engage in a Democrat-led persecution of ordinary citizens who engaged in legitimate political discourse.”
column4: Ronna McDaniel's claim of a Democrat-led persecution does not hold up when considering the individuals subpoenaed by the Jan. 6 committee. These individuals, who were involved in the submission of uncertified Trump electors, were not ordinary citizens but members of the Republican National Committee. The investigation into their actions is part of finding the facts surrounding the broader scheme to overturn the 2020 election. Legal scholars question the constitutionality of this scheme, and ongoing investigations by the Justice Department and a grand jury in Georgia are exploring potential criminal charges related to Trump's efforts to reverse his loss.

column2: “Electronic voting machines didn't allow people to vote” in Maricopa County, Arizona.
column4: In Maricopa County, Arizona, some polling centers faced glitches with tabulator machines during the election. However, there were no reports of voters being turned away or unable to vote. Technicians worked to resolve the issue, fixing the settings on nearly all the printers. Polling centers with no wait times were available for frustrated voters to cast their ballots. The Republican National Committee and others filed a lawsuit to extend polling hours beyond 7 p.m., which was denied by a Maricopa County judge. The judge stated that there was no evidence of voters being disenfranchised.

column2: Photos show celebrities reacting to Will Smith slapping Chris Rock.
column4: A grid of 12 photos circulating online shows celebrities' shocked reactions to an incident involving Will Smith and Chris Rock at the Academy Awards. However, a reverse image search reveals that this is not the case. The photos were taken in 2017 when there was a mix-up at the Oscars. 'La La Land' was incorrectly announced as the Best Picture winner, later corrected to 'Moonlight'. Celebrities like Matt Damon, Dwayne Johnson, Busy Phillips, Meryl Streep, Salma Hayek, and David Oyelowo were captured reacting to the blunder.

column2: Gun manufacturers are “the only industry in the country” that have immunity from lawsuits.
column4: Congress passed the Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act in response to extensive litigation against gun sellers and makers. President Biden falsely claims that gun manufacturers enjoy the only industry-wide immunity from being sued. However, the gun industry does face some liabilities. The law does not shield gun dealers who knowingly transfer guns for criminal use, nor those who knowingly violate state or federal law resulting in harm. Other industries, such as vaccine manufacturers, also have liability exemptions established by Congress.

column2: “Title 42 has fueled the border crisis. In 2019, 7 percent of illegal border crossings were repeated crossings. Today the rate is 27 percent.”
column4: Title 42, implemented by President Donald Trump, is under scrutiny as the border crisis intensifies. Critics argue that the lack of collateral consequences under Title 42, highlighted by Aaron Reichlin-Melnick, allows migrants to evade immigration decisions and avoid being logged into Border Patrols databases. As a result, repeat crossings have surged from 7% to 27%. However, the surge in border crossings is driven by various factors, including the pandemic response, natural disasters, and economic conditions.

column2: Sarasota, Florida, teachers told they cannot purchase books, accept donated reading materials, order from Scholastic or hold book fairs.
column4: Sarasota County Schools paused book purchases and donations to comply with a new law that requires age-appropriate book selection. The district will provide Florida's Department of Education with enough time to interpret and train personnel on HB 1467. Teachers can choose reading materials for their classrooms, but each book must undergo a review process. Scholastic orders by students and book fairs are still permitted, with a suggestion to reschedule some fairs.
